message_1:
Determine the radius of convergence of the power series
$$\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^n(z-4)^n}{n!}.$$
Hints: Use the ratio test and the definition of the radius of convergence of a power series.
message_2:
To determine the radius of convergence of the given power series, we will use the Ratio Test. The Ratio Test states that if the limit as n approaches infinity of the absolute value of the ratio of consecutive terms of a series is less than 1, then the series converges. In this case, we have:

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}\right| = \lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{\frac{(-1)^{n+1}(z-4)^{n+1}}{(n+1)!}}{\frac{(-1)^n(z-4)^n}{n!}}\right|$$

Simplify the expression:

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{(-1)^{n+1}(z-4)^{n+1}(n!)}{(-1)^n(z-4)^n(n+1)!}\right|$$

Cancel out the common terms:

$$\lim_{n\to\infty}\left|\frac{(z-4)}{n+1}\right|$$

As n approaches infinity, the expression inside the absolute value converges to 0. Since 0 < 1, the power series converges for all values of z. Therefore, the radius of convergence is infinite.
